The Related Discourses

13. The Noble Path

28. The Other Shore (3)

Thus have I heard:1 One time, the Buddha stayed in the kingdom of Śrāvastī at Anāthapiṇḍada Park in Jeta Grove.

The Venerable Ānanda then came to visit the Buddha, prostrated at his feet, and withdrew to sit at one side. He said, “Bhagavān, there is what is not the other shore and what is the other shore. Bhagavān, what is not the other shore, and what is the other shore?”

The Buddha told Ānanda, “Wrong view is not the other shore, but right view is the other shore. Wrong intention, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong concentration are not the other shore, but right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right concentration are the other shore.”

The Bhagavān then spoke in verse:

  1. “Rare are the people who can
    Cross over to the other shore;
    Everyone else in the world
    Wander around on this shore.
  1. Of this right teaching and discipline,
    There are some who can follow it;
    They are the ones who can cross over
    That difficult ford of birth-and-death.”

After the Buddha had taught this discourse, the monks who heard what the Buddha had taught rejoiced and handed it down.

Endnotes

  1. This sutra is reconstituted from a description after SA 13.26 at 200b11. It’s parallel with AN 10.117 and SN 45.34, but the Pali doesn’t have this interlocutor as a variant.
Translator: Charles Patton
